# Iris Data Set

## Introduction
The **Iris flower data set** or **Fisherâ€™s Iris data set** is a multivariate data set introduced by the British statistician and biologist Ronald Fisher in his 1936 paper *The use of multiple measurements in taxonomic problems* as an example of [linear discriminant analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_discriminant_analysis).

## Numeric Summaries by Species
Words about what they look at below.

```{r numeric, echo = F}
#Write function for summary of data with rounding
summary_round <- function(data, round_number){
  min <- round(sapply(data, min), round_number)
  q1 <- round(sapply(data, quantile, probs=c(0.25)), round_number)
  median <- round(sapply(data, median), round_number)
  mean <- round(sapply(data, mean), round_number)
  q3 <- round(sapply(data, quantile,probs=c(0.75)), round_number)
  max <- round(sapply(data, max), round_number)
  result <- t(data.frame(min, q1, median, mean, q3, max))
  result <- data.frame(result)
  row.names(result) <- c("Min.", "1st Qu.", "Median", "Mean", "3rd Qu.", "Max")
  return(result)
}

species_summary <- function(species){
  species_data <- iris %>% filter(Species == species) %>% select(-Species)
  kable(summary_round(species_data, 1), caption = paste("Summary of Species ", `species`))
}

species_summary("setosa")
species_summary("versicolor")
species_summary("virginica")
```

## Visuals

### Boxplot for Comparison
Words about what they look at below.

```{r boxplot, echo = F}
#First Graph
boxplot.1 <- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length))
boxplot.1 + geom_boxplot() +
  geom_jitter(aes(color = Species)) +
  labs(title = "Boxplot for Sepal Length")

#Second Graph
boxplot.2 <- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Width))
boxplot.2 + geom_boxplot() +
  geom_jitter(aes(color = Species)) + 
  labs(title = "Boxplot for Sepal Width")
```

### Multiple Distributions Present
Words about what they look at below.

```{r multiple, echo = F}
#First Graph
multiple.1 <- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length))
multiple.1 + geom_histogram(aes(y = ..density..), bins = 20) +
  geom_density(size = 3, color = "red", adjust = 0.4)  +
  labs(title = "Histogram for Sepal Length")

#Second Graph
multiple.2 <- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length))
multiple.2 + geom_histogram(aes(y = ..density..), bins = 20) +
  geom_density(color = "red", size = 2)  +
  labs(title = "Histogram for Sepal Length")+
  facet_wrap(. ~ Species)
```

### Scatterplot
Words about what they look at below.

```{r scatter, echo = F, message= F}
#First Graph
scatter.1 <- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width))
scatter.1 + geom_point(aes(color = Species)) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, aes(group = Species), color = "green") +
  labs(title = "Sepal Length vs Sepal Width")

#Second Graph
scatter.2 <- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Petal.Length, y = Petal.Width))
scatter.2 + geom_point(aes(color = Species)) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, aes(group = Species), color = "green") +
  labs(title = "Petal Length vs Petal Width")
```
